title: How to Send Wedding Invitations

steps.headline: Finalize your guest list at least 4-6 months before the wedding.
steps.description: You’ll need to be absolutely sure of who you want to invite before you start sending out invitations or even save-the-dates. Sit down with your future spouse and work out your guest list as soon as possible. If you’re planning a destination wedding, it’s even more crucial to finalize your guest list right away. Try to determine exactly who you’re going to invite 9 months to a year in advance.

steps.headline: Send save-the-dates 4-6 months before the wedding if you like.
steps.description: Save-the-dates are a totally optional heads up to the people on your guest list. If you choose to send out save-the-dates, do so about 4-6 months in advance if you can. This will give your guests plenty of time to plan ahead and clear space on their calendars for the big day. Save-the-dates are a great idea if you’re having a destination wedding or if a lot of your guests live far away and need to travel to attend. In these situations, try to send out your save-the-dates at least 9 months in advance.

steps.headline: Post your invitations 6-8 weeks before the wedding.
steps.description: Aim to get your invitations into the mail about 2 months before the event so that your guests have time to plan and RSVP. Make sure your invitation includes any crucial information the guests might need, including the time and location of the wedding and whether they can bring children or a plus one.Tip: If you’re planning other events around the wedding as well, such as a shower or bachelor/bachelorette party, those invitations should be sent out at least 4-6 weeks before the event in question. If you want to have an engagement party, send out invites as soon as possible after the engagement. If you didn’t send save-the-dates, you might want to send out your invitations a little earlier (e.g., 3-4 months in advance).

steps.headline: Mail invitations for destination weddings at least 12 weeks in advance.
steps.description: If your wedding is going to involve a lot of travel, your guests will need extra time to plan. Send your invitations out at least 4 months ahead of time, especially if you didn’t send save-the-dates. This also applies to guests who need to travel across country or overseas to attend your wedding. Make sure your guests have access to information about transportation and hotel accommodations for their stay as soon as possible. You can either include this information in the invitations or provide it separately (e.g., on your wedding website or in a separate email). If only a few of your guests have to travel long-distance, call or email them in advance of sending out your printed invitations.

steps.headline: Ask guests to RSVP 2 weeks to 1 month in advance.
steps.description: Sending out invitations early gives both you and your guests extra time to plan. Include a “Please RSVP by” date in your invitations that’s at least 2 to 4 weeks in advance of the wedding date. That will give you time to make adjustments to you catering arrangements, seating plans, and other details that might be affected by the number of guests. Give your guests the option to RSVP by email or phone as well as by mail. This is an especially helpful option if you’re planning your wedding last-minute or if you regularly use email or phone to communicate with your guests.

steps.headline: Use each guest’s full name and title.
steps.description:
When writing out the addresses on your invitation envelopes, include the full name of each guest. Don’t use initials or leave out their last names, unless you’re addressing a very close family member or friend. Include titles as well, such as Mr., Mrs., Ms./Miss, or Dr. If you’re addressing a married couple that shares a surname, you can just use the full name of whichever member of the couple you know best. For example, “Mrs. and Mrs. Jane Reynolds Thomson.”
If you’re addressing a single person and want to invite them to bring a plus one, write “and guest” after their name on the inner envelope. Write only the name of the main guest on the outer envelope. If you’re only using one envelope, simply include a note saying that they are welcome to bring a guest.

steps.headline: Add the names of any children you want to invite below their parents’ names.
steps.description: If you’re inviting any children under 18 to your wedding, write their first names on the envelope below the names of their parents. If you’re using double envelopes, write the children’s names on the inner envelope only, under their parents’ names.Tip: If your wedding is adults-only and you get an RSVP from a guest that includes their kids, have a phone conversation with them. Politely but firmly remind them that you are not inviting any kids to the wedding and that you’re not able to make exceptions. If they’re really upset or it means a lot to you for them to be there, consider offering to hire a babysitter to watch their kids during the wedding. If you don’t want to invite the children, simply omit their names from the invitation. Once you’ve sent the invitations out, call up any guests with children and explain to them that you’re not able to accommodate kids at your wedding. You can also mention that the wedding is adults-only on your wedding website. If any guests have kids over 18 that you want to invite, address them on the invitation the same way you would any adult guest.

steps.headline: Write out the guests’ addresses fully, without abbreviations.
steps.description:
If you’re going for a really traditional wedding invitation, don’t use any abbreviations whatsoever. For example, instead of “St.,” write out “Street.” Write out “Apartment” instead of “Apt.” and “South” instead of “S.”
For instance, your address might look like:
Mr. Bertram Wilberforce Wooster and Mr. Reginald Jeeves
23 South Plum Street
Long Island City, NY, 11101

Traditionally, if you’re living in the U.S., you would also write out the full name of your state. However, the USPS generally prefers the use of 2-letter postal abbreviations.

steps.headline: Print your return address on the back flap of the outer envelope.
steps.description: Instead of placing your return address in the usual upper left-hand corner position, write it out on the envelope’s back flap. Make sure to use the address that you’d like guests to RSVP to (or send gifts, if they can’t attend the wedding in person). Occasionally, mail sorting machines mistake the return address on the back flap for the recipient’s address, with the result that the invitation might get sent back to you. To prevent this from happening, make the address on the front larger and more prominent than the return address on the back.

steps.headline: Give yourself a few weeks to assemble the invitations.
steps.description:
Putting together wedding invitations can be time consuming, so give yourself plenty of time in advance before you actually send them. Give yourself at least 2-3 weeks to:
Finalize your guest list and confirm the names and addresses of all your guests
Make or order the invitations and any additional materials, such as maps, RSVP cards, and extra envelopes
Fill and address the envelopes

steps.headline: Weigh a completed invitation at the post office to calculate postage correctly.
steps.description: Wedding invitations often cost more to send than regular mail. Before you start putting stamps on your envelopes, assemble a full invitation and bring it to your post office. Ask them if they can weigh it for you and tell you how much postage you need. If you have any guests living overseas, you’ll need to take international postage into account. You might also need additional postage for envelopes that include extra materials (like maps for out-of-town guests).

steps.headline: Purchase wedding-themed stamps if you like.
steps.description: Many post offices have wedding-themed stamps that are worth slightly more postage than regular stamps. Ask at your post office if they have these stamps when you bring in your invitations to be weighed. If your local branch doesn’t have wedding stamps, you may be able to order them online.

steps.headline: Ask at the post office if they can hand-cancel your stamps.
steps.description: When you’re ready to mail the invitations, ask about getting the stamps postmarked by hand rather than by machine. This will reduce the risk of damage to your invitations, and will also make them look prettier and more traditional.Tip: Whether or not you request hand-canceling or other special handling for your invitations, it’s always best to bring them into the post office and hand them to a postal worker in person. They’re less likely to get lost or damaged that way, and the post office employees can also help you ensure that they’re addressed and stamped correctly.

steps.headline: Send save-the-dates by email to save time and money.
steps.description: While it’s traditional to send your actual wedding invitations in the mail, save-the-dates are another matter. Feel free to send out a simple save-the-date email to your friends and family. You can also send out some nice e-cards or digital invitations if you want to do something fancier than a basic email.

steps.headline: Use email to send out supplemental information to guests.
steps.description: Email is also a great way to send out information that you’d otherwise have to stuff into your invitation envelopes. Save paper and postage by sending out emails with information about dress code, transportation, hotel arrangements, gift registries, or anything else you’d like your guests to know about. You can also put this information on your wedding website. Include the URL in your invitations so your guests will know where to look for it.

steps.headline: Give printed invitations to close friends and family in person.
steps.description: Unless they’re huge sticklers for formality, there’s no need to ship an invitation off to someone you see every day. Put the invitation in an envelope and write out the recipients’ names on it, but hand-deliver it to them rather than putting it in the mail. If you choose to do this, though, make sure you hand it over directly to the recipient(s) rather than just leaving it somewhere for them (like their mailbox at work). This will give the delivery a more personal touch.

steps.headline: Make digital invitations if you want a less formal vibe.
steps.description: Online wedding invitations are less traditional than paper ones, but they’re becoming an increasingly acceptable option. In addition to being cheaper and more environmentally friendly than paper invitations, they’re also more convenient for both you and your guests! Consider sending digital wedding invitations through a service like Greenvelope, Evite, or Paperless Post. Most companies that provide online wedding invitations offer a huge variety of designs and customization options, so your invitations will still look just as lovely as their paper counterparts! If you have older or more traditional guests who wouldn’t appreciate getting an electronic invitation, you can still send paper invitations to those guests.
